message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Safe Learning in Robotics: From Learning-Based Control to Safe Reinforcement Learning
Paper Abstract: The last half decade has seen a steep rise in the number of contributions on safe learning methods for real-world robotic deployments from both the control and reinforcement learning communities. This article provides a concise but holistic review of the recent advances made in using machine learning to achieve safe decision-making under uncertainties, with a focus on unifying the language and frameworks used in control theory and reinforcement learning research. It includes learning-based control approaches that safely improve performance by learning the uncertain dynamics, reinforcement learning approaches that encourage safety or robustness, and methods that can formally certify the safety of a learned control policy. As data- and learning-based robot control methods continue to gain traction, researchers must understand when and how to best leverage them in real-world scenarios where safety is imperative, such as when operating in close proximityto humans. We highlight some of the open challenges that will drive the field of robot learning in the coming years, and emphasize the need for realistic physics-based benchmarks to facilitate fair comparisons between control and reinforcement learning approaches.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Search Results for "Robotics"

Here's a comprehensive overview of robotics from the search results:

### Definition and Overview

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.

### Key Components of Robotics

Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms. Robot systems typically combine three main aspects:

1. **Mechanical Construction**: A frame, form or shape designed to achieve a particular task.

2. **Electrical Components**: Used for movement (through motors), sensing (where electrical signals are used to measure things like heat, sound, position, and energy status), and operation.

3. **Software**: A program is how a robot decides when or how to do something.

### Types and Applications

There are various specialized areas within robotics:

- **Soft Robotics**: A subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.

- **Robotic Arms**: A type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

- **Hexapod Robots**: A mechanical vehicle that walks on six legs.

### Industry Growth

In the 21st century, investment in robotics companies has grown due to increasing demand for automation.

Here are the search results for "Machine learning":

## Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Key Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms, supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.(no content)Supervised learning uses a set of paired inputs and desired outputs, with the learning task being to produce the desired output for each input.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Historical Development

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Neural Networks

A neural network or neural net (NN), also called artificial neural network (ANN), is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks, consisting of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons.

Web search results for query: "Reinforcement learning"

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Self-play (reinforcement learning technique) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-play_(reinforcement_learning_technique)"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Category:Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Self-supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-supervised_learning"},{"title":"Imitation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imitation_learning"}]

## Overview

Here's a comprehensive overview of reinforcement learning based on the search results:

**Definition and Core Concept**

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

**Key Mechanism**

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

**Applications**

It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

**Deep Reinforcement Learning**

Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning. Deep RL incorporates deep learning into the solution, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

**Recent Achievements**

AlphaGo, a computer program trained with deep RL to play Go, became the first computer Go program to beat a human professional Go player without handicap on a full-sized 19×19 board.

Links: [{"title":"Supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supervised_learning"},{"title":"Weak supervision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semi-supervised_learning"},{"title":"Self-supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-supervised_learning"},{"title":"Machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning"},{"title":"Imitation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imitation_learning"},{"title":"Feature learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feature_learning"},{"title":"Similarity learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Similarity_learning"},{"title":"Deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning"},{"title":"Active learning (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_learning_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Generative adversarial network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_adversarial_network"}]

## Supervised Learning

In machine learning, supervised learning (SL) is a type of machine learning paradigm where an algorithm learns to map input data to a specific output based on example input-output pairs.(no content)This process involves training a statistical model using labeled data, meaning each piece of input data is provided with the correct output.

### How It Works

For instance, if you want a model to identify cats in images, supervised learning would involve feeding it many images of cats (inputs) that are explicitly labeled "cat" (outputs).(no content)The goal of supervised learning is for the trained model to accurately predict the output for new, unseen data. This requires the algorithm to effectively generalize from the training examples, a quality measured by its generalization error.

### Common Applications

Supervised learning is commonly used for tasks like classification (predicting a category, e.g., spam or not spam) and regression (predicting a continuous value, e.g., house prices).

### Key Challenges

Generally, there is a tradeoff between bias and variance. A learning algorithm with low bias must be "flexible" so that it can fit the data well. But if the learning algorithm is too flexible, it will fit each training data set differently, and hence have high variance. A key aspect of many supervised learning methods is that they are able to adjust this tradeoff between bias and variance (either automatically or by providing a bias/variance parameter that the user can adjust).

I've completed the web search for "Control theory" and found comprehensive information about this topic. Here's what I found:

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How Control Systems Work

A controller monitors the controlled process variable and compares it with the reference or set point. The difference between actual and desired value, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems in the natural and behavioral sciences, and is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Links: [{"title":"Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_quantification"},{"title":"Quantification of margins and uncertainties - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantification_of_margins_and_uncertainties"},{"title":"Talk:Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Uncertainty_quantification"},{"title":"Uncertainty analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_analysis"},{"title":"Talk:Numerical methods for partial differential equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Numerical_partial_differential_equations"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Climate change/Figures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Climate_change/Figures"},{"title":"Talk:Info-gap decision theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Info-gap_decision_theory"},{"title":"Oil and gas reserves and resource quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contingent_resources"},{"title":"Integrated Carbon Observation System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_Carbon_Observation_System"}]

## Uncertainty Quantification

Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is the science of quantitative characterization and estimation of uncertainties in both computational and real world applications.(no content)It tries to determine how likely certain outcomes are if some aspects of the system are not exactly known.

### Key Concepts

There are two major types of problems in uncertainty quantification: one is the forward propagation of uncertainty (where the various sources of uncertainty are propagated through the model to predict the overall uncertainty in the system response) and the other is the inverse assessment of model uncertainty and parameter uncertainty (where the model parameters are calibrated simultaneously using test data).

### Types of Uncertainty

The field recognizes different categories of uncertainty. Epistemic uncertainty represents a lack of knowledge about the appropriate value to use for a quantity, and is sometimes referred to as state of knowledge uncertainty, subjective uncertainty, Type B, or reducible uncertainty, meaning that the uncertainty can be reduced through increased understanding (research), or increased and more relevant data. In contrast, uncertainty characterized by inherent randomness which cannot be reduced by further data is called aleatory uncertainty; some examples of aleatory uncertainty are weather or the height of individuals in a population.

### Approaches

Existing uncertainty propagation approaches include probabilistic approaches and non-probabilistic approaches, with six categories of probabilistic approaches including simulation-based methods such as Monte Carlo simulations, importance sampling, and adaptive sampling.

## Uncertainty Quantification

Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is the science of quantitative characterization and estimation of uncertainties in both computational and real world applications.(no content)It tries to determine how likely certain outcomes are if some aspects of the system are not exactly known.

### Key Concepts

There are two major types of problems in uncertainty quantification: one is the forward propagation of uncertainty (where the various sources of uncertainty are propagated through the model to predict the overall uncertainty in the system response) and the other is the inverse assessment of model uncertainty and parameter uncertainty (where the model parameters are calibrated simultaneously using test data).

### Types of Uncertainty

The field recognizes different categories of uncertainty. Epistemic uncertainty represents a lack of knowledge about the appropriate value to use for a quantity, and is sometimes referred to as state of knowledge uncertainty, subjective uncertainty, Type B, or reducible uncertainty, meaning that the uncertainty can be reduced through increased understanding (research), or increased and more relevant data. In contrast, uncertainty characterized by inherent randomness which cannot be reduced by further data is called aleatory uncertainty; some examples of aleatory uncertainty are weather or the height of individuals in a population.

### Approaches

Existing uncertainty propagation approaches include probabilistic approaches and non-probabilistic approaches, with six categories of probabilistic approaches including simulation-based methods such as Monte Carlo simulations, importance sampling, and adaptive sampling.

## Search Results for "Robust Control"

Based on the search results, here's an overview of robust control:

### Definition and Overview

Robust control refers to theory of feedback regulation that began taking shape in the late 1970s and onwards, where modeling uncertainty is explicitly acknowledged, modeled, and taken into account in control design.(no content)The ability of a feedback control system to maintain stability and performance under uncertainty is referred to as robustness.

### Key Concepts

Tolerance to modeling uncertainty is an essential part of any feedback control scheme, that is, the ability to maintain a satisfactory level of performance when the system dynamics deviate from the nominal value used in the design.(no content)A controller designed for a particular set of model parameters is said to be robust if it also works well for values of the parameters near the nominal.

### Types of Uncertainty

Parametric uncertainty refers to the case where modeling parameters or external disturbances in feedback regulation are expected to be found within some (typically compact) set of a finite dimensional space.(no content)Non-parametric uncertainty refers to the case where the magnitude of expected modeling errors and disturbances is quantified via metrics on function spaces where these reside (infinite dimensional).

### H-Infinity Control

The term robust control became almost synonymous with the term H-infinity control, since it was the techniques in the development of the latter that gave the early impetus for the new methods.(no content)H∞ ("H-infinity") methods are used in control theory to synthesize controllers to achieve stabilization with guaranteed performance.

Web search results for query: "Policy gradient"

Links: [{"title":"Policy gradient method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Policy_gradient_method"},{"title":"Proximal policy optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proximal_Policy_Optimization"},{"title":"Actor-critic algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actor-critic_algorithm"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"}]

## Policy Gradient: Overview

Policy gradient methods are a class of reinforcement learning algorithms.(no content)Unlike value-based methods which learn a value function to derive a policy, policy optimization methods directly learn a policy function.

### How They Work

The policy gradient is a weighted average of all possible directions to increase the probability of taking any action in any state, but weighted by reward signals, so that if taking a certain action in a certain state is associated with high reward, then that direction would be highly reinforced.(no content)Policy gradient methods are used for training an RL agent whose actions are determined by a differentiable policy function by gradient ascent. Intuitively, a policy gradient method takes small policy update steps, so the agent can reach higher and higher rewards in expectation.

### Common Variants and Applications

Several important policy gradient algorithms exist:

- **REINFORCE**: REINFORCE is an on-policy algorithm, meaning that the trajectories used for the update must be sampled from the current policy.

- **Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO)**: Proximal policy optimization (PPO) is a reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm for training an intelligent agent. Specifically, it is a policy gradient method, often used for deep RL when the policy network is very large.

- **Actor-Critic Methods**: The actor-critic algorithm (AC) is a family of reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms that combine policy-based RL algorithms such as policy gradient methods, and value-based RL algorithms. An AC algorithm consists of two main components: an "actor" that determines which actions to take according to a policy function, and a "critic" that evaluates those actions according to a value function.

Links: [{"title":"Safety engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety_engineering"},{"title":"Category:Safety engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Safety_engineering"},{"title":"Safety engineer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety_engineer"},{"title":"Canadian Society of Safety Engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Society_of_Safety_Engineering"},{"title":"Software safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_safety"},{"title":"Fire protection engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fire_protection_engineering"},{"title":"Process safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_safety"},{"title":"Safety-critical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety-critical_system"},{"title":"Factor of safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factor_of_safety"},{"title":"Reliability engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reliability_engineering"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of safety engineering:

## Definition and Purpose

Safety engineering is an engineering discipline which assures that engineered systems provide acceptable levels of safety.(no content)It is strongly related to industrial engineering/systems engineering, and the subset system safety engineering.(no content)Safety engineering assures that a life-critical system behaves as needed, even when components fail.

## Analysis Techniques

Analysis techniques can be split into two categories: qualitative and quantitative methods. Both approaches share the goal of finding causal dependencies between a hazard on system level and failures of individual components.(no content)The two most common fault modeling techniques are called failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) and fault tree analysis (FTA).

## Safety Standards and Levels

Usually a failure in safety-certified systems is acceptable if, on average, less than one life per 10⁹ hours of continuous operation is lost to failure. Most Western nuclear reactors, medical equipment, and commercial aircraft are certified to this level.

## Related Disciplines

Safety engineering encompasses various specialized areas including construction and engineering, architectural design of systems, fire protection, ergonomics, system and process safety, system safety, safety and health program management, accident investigation and analysis, product safety, construction safety, education and training methods, measurement of safety performance, human behavior, environmental safety and health, and safety, health and environmental laws, regulations and standards.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of safety engineering:

## Definition and Purpose

Safety engineering is an engineering discipline which assures that engineered systems provide acceptable levels of safety.(no content)It is strongly related to industrial engineering/systems engineering, and the subset system safety engineering.(no content)Safety engineering assures that a life-critical system behaves as needed, even when components fail.

## Analysis Techniques

Analysis techniques can be split into two categories: qualitative and quantitative methods. Both approaches share the goal of finding causal dependencies between a hazard on system level and failures of individual components.(no content)The two most common fault modeling techniques are called failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) and fault tree analysis (FTA).

## Safety Standards and Levels

Usually a failure in safety-certified systems is acceptable if, on average, less than one life per 10⁹ hours of continuous operation is lost to failure. Most Western nuclear reactors, medical equipment, and commercial aircraft are certified to this level.

## Related Disciplines

Safety engineering encompasses various specialized areas including construction and engineering, architectural design of systems, fire protection, ergonomics, system and process safety, system safety, safety and health program management, accident investigation and analysis, product safety, construction safety, education and training methods, measurement of safety performance, human behavior, environmental safety and health, and safety, health and environmental laws, regulations and standards.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the robotics paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** SURVEY
- The paper is a survey/literature review of safe learning methods for robotics, as it "provides a concise but holistic review of the recent advances" in the field.

**Triples Identified and Validated:** 9 triples

The paper reviews the following key technologies and methodologies:

1. **Reinforcement learning** - A machine learning paradigm used for training agents through interaction with environments
2. **Machine learning** - The overarching field that encompasses safe decision-making methods
3. **Control theory** - Unified with RL approaches for safe robot learning
4. **Robotics** - The primary application domain for safe learning
5. **Safety engineering** - Core concern for systems operating near humans
6. **Uncertainty quantification** - Methods for handling uncertain dynamics
7. **Policy gradient method** - Key RL technique for safe robot control
8. **Robust control** - Approaches for performance under uncertainty
9. **Supervised learning** - Used within learning-based control for dynamics modeling

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED
- All 9 triples have valid Wikipedia URLs
- Paper type correctly set to "survey"
- All entity types properly categorized (6 methods, 2 concepts, 1 task)
- All relations correctly marked as "uses" (appropriate for a survey paper)

Sources:
- [Reinforcement learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning)
- [Machine learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics)
- [Safety engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety_engineering)

- [Robust control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control)
